trans-unit.target: Using elastic database client library with Entity Framework

trans-unit.source: Elastic database client makes it easy to scale, and Entity Framework is easy to use for coding databases
trans-unit.target: Elastic database client makes it easy to scale, and Entity Framework is easy to use for coding databases

trans-unit.source: Elastic Database client library with Entity Framework
trans-unit.target: Elastic Database client library with Entity Framework

trans-unit.source: You can use the elastic database client library with Microsoft’s Entity Framework (EF) to build applications that take advantage of database sharding, facilitating scaling-out your application's data tier.
trans-unit.target: You can use the elastic database client library with Microsoft’s Entity Framework (EF) to build applications that take advantage of database sharding, facilitating scaling-out your application's data tier.

trans-unit.source: This document shows the changes in an Entity Framework application that are needed to integrate with the elastic database tools' capabilities.
trans-unit.target: This document shows the changes in an Entity Framework application that are needed to integrate with the elastic database tools' capabilities.

trans-unit.source: The focus is on composing shard map management and data-dependent routing with the Entity Framework Code First approach.
trans-unit.target: The focus is on composing shard map management and data-dependent routing with the Entity Framework Code First approach.

trans-unit.source: The <link><linkText>Code First – New Database</linkText><title></title></link> tutorial for EF serves as our running example throughout this document.
trans-unit.target: The <link><linkText>Code First – New Database</linkText><title></title></link> tutorial for EF serves as our running example throughout this document.

trans-unit.source: Entity Framework workflows
trans-unit.target: Entity Framework workflows

trans-unit.source: Entity Framework developers rely on one of the following four workflows to build applications and to ensure persistence for application objects:
trans-unit.target: Entity Framework developers rely on one of the following four workflows to build applications and to ensure persistence for application objects:

trans-unit.source: Code First (New Database): The EF developer creates the model in the application code and then EF generates the database from it.
trans-unit.target: Code First (New Database): The EF developer creates the model in the application code and then EF generates the database from it.

trans-unit.source: Code First (Existing Database): The developer lets EF generate the application code for the model from an existing database.
trans-unit.target: Code First (Existing Database): The developer lets EF generate the application code for the model from an existing database.

trans-unit.source: Model First: The developer creates the model in the EF designer and then EF creates the database from the model.
trans-unit.target: Model First: The developer creates the model in the EF designer and then EF creates the database from the model.

trans-unit.source: Database First: The developer uses EF tooling to infer the model from an existing database.
trans-unit.target: Database First: The developer uses EF tooling to infer the model from an existing database.

trans-unit.source: All these approaches rely on the DbContext class to transparently manage database connections and database schema for an application.
trans-unit.target: All these approaches rely on the DbContext class to transparently manage database connections and database schema for an application.

trans-unit.source: As we will discuss in more detail later in the document, different constructors on the DbContext base class allow for different levels of control over connection creation, database bootstrapping and schema creation.
trans-unit.target: As we will discuss in more detail later in the document, different constructors on the DbContext base class allow for different levels of control over connection creation, database bootstrapping and schema creation.

trans-unit.source: Challenges arise primarily from the fact that the database connection management provided by EF intersects with the connection management capabilities of the data dependent routing interfaces provided by the elastic database client library.
trans-unit.target: Challenges arise primarily from the fact that the database connection management provided by EF intersects with the connection management capabilities of the data dependent routing interfaces provided by the elastic database client library.

trans-unit.source: Elastic database tools assumptions
trans-unit.target: Elastic database tools assumptions

trans-unit.source: For term definitions, see <link><linkText>Elastic Database tools glossary</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For term definitions, see <link><linkText>Elastic Database tools glossary</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: With elastic database client library, you define partitions of your application data called shardlets.
trans-unit.target: With elastic database client library, you define partitions of your application data called shardlets.

trans-unit.source: Shardlets are identified by a sharding key and are mapped to specific databases.
trans-unit.target: Shardlets are identified by a sharding key and are mapped to specific databases.

trans-unit.source: An application may have as many databases as needed and distribute the shardlets to provide enough capacity or performance given current business requirements.
trans-unit.target: An application may have as many databases as needed and distribute the shardlets to provide enough capacity or performance given current business requirements.

trans-unit.source: The mapping of sharding key values to the databases is stored by a shard map provided by the elastic database client APIs.
trans-unit.target: The mapping of sharding key values to the databases is stored by a shard map provided by the elastic database client APIs.

trans-unit.source: We call this capability Shard Map Management, or SMM for short.
trans-unit.target: We call this capability Shard Map Management, or SMM for short.

trans-unit.source: The shard map also serves as the broker of database connections for requests that carry a sharding key.
trans-unit.target: The shard map also serves as the broker of database connections for requests that carry a sharding key.

trans-unit.source: We refer to this capability as data-dependent routing.
trans-unit.target: We refer to this capability as data-dependent routing.

trans-unit.source: The shard map manager protects users from inconsistent views into shardlet data that can occur when concurrent shardlet management operations (such as relocating data from one shard to another) are happening.
trans-unit.target: The shard map manager protects users from inconsistent views into shardlet data that can occur when concurrent shardlet management operations (such as relocating data from one shard to another) are happening.

trans-unit.source: To do so, the shard maps managed by the client library broker the database connections for an application.
trans-unit.target: To do so, the shard maps managed by the client library broker the database connections for an application.

trans-unit.source: This allows the shard map functionality to automatically kill a database connection when shard management operations could impact the shardlet that the connection has been created for.
trans-unit.target: This allows the shard map functionality to automatically kill a database connection when shard management operations could impact the shardlet that the connection has been created for.

trans-unit.source: This approach needs to integrate with some of EF’s functionality, such as creating new connections from an existing one to check for database existence.
trans-unit.target: This approach needs to integrate with some of EF’s functionality, such as creating new connections from an existing one to check for database existence.

trans-unit.source: In general, our observation has been that the standard DbContext constructors only work reliably for closed database connections that can safely be cloned for EF work.
trans-unit.target: In general, our observation has been that the standard DbContext constructors only work reliably for closed database connections that can safely be cloned for EF work.

trans-unit.source: The design principle of elastic database instead is to only broker opened connections.
trans-unit.target: The design principle of elastic database instead is to only broker opened connections.

trans-unit.source: One might think that closing a connection brokered by the client library before handing it over to the EF DbContext may solve this issue.
trans-unit.target: One might think that closing a connection brokered by the client library before handing it over to the EF DbContext may solve this issue.

trans-unit.source: However, by closing the connection and relying on EF to re-open it, one foregoes the validation and consistency checks performed by the library.
trans-unit.target: However, by closing the connection and relying on EF to re-open it, one foregoes the validation and consistency checks performed by the library.

trans-unit.source: The migrations functionality in EF, however, uses these connections to manage the underlying database schema in a way that is transparent to the application.
trans-unit.target: The migrations functionality in EF, however, uses these connections to manage the underlying database schema in a way that is transparent to the application.

trans-unit.source: Ideally, we would like to retain and combine all these capabilities from both the elastic database client library and EF in the same application.
trans-unit.target: Ideally, we would like to retain and combine all these capabilities from both the elastic database client library and EF in the same application.

trans-unit.source: The following section discusses these properties and requirements in more detail.
trans-unit.target: The following section discusses these properties and requirements in more detail.

trans-unit.source: Requirements
trans-unit.target: Requirements

trans-unit.source: When working with both the elastic database client library and Entity Framework APIs, we want to retain the following properties:
trans-unit.target: When working with both the elastic database client library and Entity Framework APIs, we want to retain the following properties:

trans-unit.source: Scale-out: To add or remove databases from the data tier of the sharded application as necessary for the capacity demands of the application.
trans-unit.target: Scale-out: To add or remove databases from the data tier of the sharded application as necessary for the capacity demands of the application.

trans-unit.source: This means control over the the creation and deletion of databases and using the elastic database shard map manager APIs to manage databases, and mappings of shardlets.
trans-unit.target: This means control over the the creation and deletion of databases and using the elastic database shard map manager APIs to manage databases, and mappings of shardlets.

trans-unit.source: Consistency: The application employs sharding, and uses the data dependent routing capabilities of the client library.
trans-unit.target: Consistency: The application employs sharding, and uses the data dependent routing capabilities of the client library.

trans-unit.source: To avoid corruption or wrong query results, connections are brokered through the shard map manager.
trans-unit.target: To avoid corruption or wrong query results, connections are brokered through the shard map manager.

trans-unit.source: This also retains validation and consistency.
trans-unit.target: This also retains validation and consistency.

trans-unit.source: Code First: To retain the convenience of EF’s code first paradigm.
trans-unit.target: Code First: To retain the convenience of EF’s code first paradigm.

trans-unit.source: In Code First, classes in the application are mapped transparently to the underlying database structures.
trans-unit.target: In Code First, classes in the application are mapped transparently to the underlying database structures.

trans-unit.source: The application code interacts with DbSets that mask most aspects involved in the underlying database processing.
trans-unit.target: The application code interacts with DbSets that mask most aspects involved in the underlying database processing.

trans-unit.source: Schema: Entity Framework handles initial database schema creation and subsequent schema evolution through migrations.
trans-unit.target: Schema: Entity Framework handles initial database schema creation and subsequent schema evolution through migrations.

trans-unit.source: By retaining these capabilities, adapting your app is easy as the data evolves.
trans-unit.target: By retaining these capabilities, adapting your app is easy as the data evolves.

trans-unit.source: The following guidance instructs how to satisfy these requirements for Code First applications using elastic database tools.
trans-unit.target: The following guidance instructs how to satisfy these requirements for Code First applications using elastic database tools.

trans-unit.source: Transient faults handling
trans-unit.target: Transient faults handling

trans-unit.source: The Microsoft Patterns & Practices team published the <link><linkText>The Transient Fault Handling Application Block</linkText><title></title></link>. The library is used with elastic scale client library in combination with EF. However, ensure that any transient exception returns to a place where we can ensure that the new constructor is being used after a transient fault so that any new connection attempt is made using the constructors we have tweaked. Otherwise, a connection to the correct shard is not guaranteed, and there are no assurances the connection is maintained as changes to the shard map occur.
trans-unit.target: The Microsoft Patterns & Practices team published the <link><linkText>The Transient Fault Handling Application Block</linkText><title></title></link>. The library is used with elastic scale client library in combination with EF. However, ensure that any transient exception returns to a place where we can ensure that the new constructor is being used after a transient fault so that any new connection attempt is made using the constructors we have tweaked. Otherwise, a connection to the correct shard is not guaranteed, and there are no assurances the connection is maintained as changes to the shard map occur.

trans-unit.source: SqlDatabaseUtils.SqlRetryPolicy in the code above is defined as a SqlDatabaseTransientErrorDetectionStrategy with a retry count of 10, and 5 seconds wait time between retries.
trans-unit.target: SqlDatabaseUtils.SqlRetryPolicy in the code above is defined as a SqlDatabaseTransientErrorDetectionStrategy with a retry count of 10, and 5 seconds wait time between retries.

trans-unit.source: This approach is similar to the guidance for EF and user-initiated transactions (see <link><linkText>Limitations with Retrying Execution Strategies (EF6 onwards)</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: This approach is similar to the guidance for EF and user-initiated transactions (see <link><linkText>Limitations with Retrying Execution Strategies (EF6 onwards)</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Both situations require that the application program controls the scope to which the transient exception returns: to either reopen the transaction, or (as shown) recreate the context from the proper constructor that uses the elastic database client library.
trans-unit.target: Both situations require that the application program controls the scope to which the transient exception returns: to either reopen the transaction, or (as shown) recreate the context from the proper constructor that uses the elastic database client library.

trans-unit.source: The need to control where transient exceptions take us back in scope also precludes the use of the built-in SqlAzureExecutionStrategy that comes with EF.
trans-unit.target: The need to control where transient exceptions take us back in scope also precludes the use of the built-in SqlAzureExecutionStrategy that comes with EF.

trans-unit.source: SqlAzureExecutionStrategy would reopen a connection but not use OpenConnectionForKey and therefore bypass all the validation that is performed as part of the OpenConnectionForKey call.
trans-unit.target: SqlAzureExecutionStrategy would reopen a connection but not use OpenConnectionForKey and therefore bypass all the validation that is performed as part of the OpenConnectionForKey call.

trans-unit.source: Instead, the code sample uses the built-in DefaultExecutionStrategy that also comes with EF.
trans-unit.target: Instead, the code sample uses the built-in DefaultExecutionStrategy that also comes with EF.

trans-unit.source: As opposed to SqlAzureExecutionStrategy, it works correctly in combination with the retry policy from Transient Fault Handling.
trans-unit.target: As opposed to SqlAzureExecutionStrategy, it works correctly in combination with the retry policy from Transient Fault Handling.

trans-unit.source: The execution policy is set in the ElasticScaleDbConfiguration class.
trans-unit.target: The execution policy is set in the ElasticScaleDbConfiguration class.

trans-unit.source: Note that we decided not to use DefaultSqlExecutionStrategy since it suggests to use SqlAzureExecutionStrategy if transient exceptions occur - which would lead to wrong behavior as discussed.
trans-unit.target: Note that we decided not to use DefaultSqlExecutionStrategy since it suggests to use SqlAzureExecutionStrategy if transient exceptions occur - which would lead to wrong behavior as discussed.

trans-unit.source: For more information on the different retry policies and EF, see <link><linkText>Connection Resiliency in EF</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Shard schema deployment through EF migrations
trans-unit.target: Shard schema deployment through EF migrations

trans-unit.source: Automatic schema management is a convenience provided by the Entity Framework.
trans-unit.target: Automatic schema management is a convenience provided by the Entity Framework.

trans-unit.source: In the context of applications using elastic database tools, we want to retain this capability to automatically provision the schema to newly created shards when databases are added to the sharded application.
trans-unit.target: In the context of applications using elastic database tools, we want to retain this capability to automatically provision the schema to newly created shards when databases are added to the sharded application.

trans-unit.source: The primary use case is to increase capacity at the data tier for sharded applications using EF.
trans-unit.target: The primary use case is to increase capacity at the data tier for sharded applications using EF.

trans-unit.source: Relying on EF’s capabilities for schema management reduces the database administration effort with a sharded application built on EF.
trans-unit.target: Relying on EF’s capabilities for schema management reduces the database administration effort with a sharded application built on EF.

trans-unit.source: Schema deployment through EF migrations works best on unopened connections.
trans-unit.target: Schema deployment through EF migrations works best on unopened connections.

trans-unit.source: This is in contrast to the scenario for data dependent routing that relies on the opened connection provided by the elastic database client API.
trans-unit.target: This is in contrast to the scenario for data dependent routing that relies on the opened connection provided by the elastic database client API.

trans-unit.source: Another difference is the consistency requirement: While desirable to ensure consistency for all data-dependent routing connections to protect against concurrent shard map manipulation, it is not a concern with initial schema deployment to a new database that has not yet been registered in the shard map, and not yet been allocated to hold shardlets.
trans-unit.target: Another difference is the consistency requirement: While desirable to ensure consistency for all data-dependent routing connections to protect against concurrent shard map manipulation, it is not a concern with initial schema deployment to a new database that has not yet been registered in the shard map, and not yet been allocated to hold shardlets.

trans-unit.source: We can therefore rely on regular database connections for this scenarios, as opposed to data-dependent routing.
trans-unit.target: We can therefore rely on regular database connections for this scenarios, as opposed to data-dependent routing.

trans-unit.source: This leads to an approach where schema deployment through EF migrations is tightly coupled with the registration of the new database as a shard in the application’s shard map.
trans-unit.target: This leads to an approach where schema deployment through EF migrations is tightly coupled with the registration of the new database as a shard in the application’s shard map.

trans-unit.source: This relies on the following prerequisites:
trans-unit.target: This relies on the following prerequisites:

trans-unit.source: The database has already been created.
trans-unit.target: The database has already been created.

trans-unit.source: The database is empty – it holds no user schema and no user data.
trans-unit.target: The database is empty – it holds no user schema and no user data.

trans-unit.source: The database cannot yet be accessed through the elastic database client APIs for data-dependent routing.
trans-unit.target: The database cannot yet be accessed through the elastic database client APIs for data-dependent routing.

trans-unit.source: With these prerequisites in place, we can create a regular un-opened SqlConnection to kick off EF migrations for schema deployment.
trans-unit.target: With these prerequisites in place, we can create a regular un-opened SqlConnection to kick off EF migrations for schema deployment.

trans-unit.source: Limitations
trans-unit.target: Limitations

trans-unit.source: The approaches outlined in this document entail a couple of limitations:
trans-unit.target: The approaches outlined in this document entail a couple of limitations:

trans-unit.source: EF applications that use LocalDb first need to migrate to a regular SQL Server database before using elastic database client library.
trans-unit.target: EF applications that use LocalDb first need to migrate to a regular SQL Server database before using elastic database client library.

trans-unit.source: Scaling out an application through sharding with Elastic Scale is not possible with LocalDb.
trans-unit.target: Scaling out an application through sharding with Elastic Scale is not possible with LocalDb.

trans-unit.source: Note that development can still use LocalDb.
trans-unit.target: Note that development can still use LocalDb.

trans-unit.source: Any changes to the application that imply database schema changes need to go through EF migrations on all shards.
trans-unit.target: Any changes to the application that imply database schema changes need to go through EF migrations on all shards.

trans-unit.source: The sample code for this document does not demonstrate how to do this.
trans-unit.target: The sample code for this document does not demonstrate how to do this.

trans-unit.source: Consider using Update-Database with a ConnectionString parameter to iterate over all shards; or extract the T-SQL script for the pending migration using Update-Database with the –Script option and apply the T-SQL script to your shards.
trans-unit.target: Consider using Update-Database with a ConnectionString parameter to iterate over all shards; or extract the T-SQL script for the pending migration using Update-Database with the –Script option and apply the T-SQL script to your shards.

trans-unit.source: Given a request, it is assumed that all of its database processing is contained within a single shard as identified by the sharding key provided by the request.
trans-unit.target: Given a request, it is assumed that all of its database processing is contained within a single shard as identified by the sharding key provided by the request.

trans-unit.source: However, this assumption does not always hold true.
trans-unit.target: However, this assumption does not always hold true.

trans-unit.source: For example, when it is not possible to make a sharding key available.
trans-unit.target: For example, when it is not possible to make a sharding key available.

trans-unit.source: Conclusions
trans-unit.target: Conclusions

trans-unit.source: Entity Framework applications can easily benefit from the elastic database tools in Azure SQL Database.
trans-unit.target: Entity Framework applications can easily benefit from the elastic database tools in Azure SQL Database.

trans-unit.source: Through the steps outlined in this document, EF applications can use the elastic database client library's capability for data dependent routing by refactoring constructors of the DbContext subclasses used in the EF application.
trans-unit.target: Through the steps outlined in this document, EF applications can use the elastic database client library's capability for data dependent routing by refactoring constructors of the DbContext subclasses used in the EF application.

trans-unit.source: This limits the changes required to those places where DbContext classes already exist.
trans-unit.target: This limits the changes required to those places where DbContext classes already exist.

trans-unit.source: In addition, EF applications can continue to benefit from automatic schema deployment by combining the steps that invoke the necessary EF migrations with the registration of new shards and mappings in the shard map.
trans-unit.target: In addition, EF applications can continue to benefit from automatic schema deployment by combining the steps that invoke the necessary EF migrations with the registration of new shards and mappings in the shard map.
